content.webTitle: Casey Dellacqua's US Open challenge ended by Flavia Pennetta

fields.headline: Casey Dellacqua's US Open challenge ended by Flavia Pennetta
fields.bodyText: Sometimes the big stage is just too big – as Australia’s Casey Dellacqua discovered at the end of her thrilling run in the US Open on day eight, the second time this year she has reached the second week of a slam. The Italian 11th seed Flavia Pennetta beat her 7-5, 6-2 and meets Serena Williams in the quarter-finals on Wednesday, with Victoria Azarenka likely to be waiting for her in the semi-finals. Pennetta was all-round too strong for Dellacqua who, at 29, is having probably her best season, having also reached the fourth round in Melbourne this year, and she returns to Perth with plenty of quality tennis to take into a three-week Asia swing. On her way to the fourth round here, she beat the rising Czech Karolina Pliskova, who had just put former world No1 and eighth seed Ana Ivanovic out of the tournament, then gave Pennetta a solid challenge on Arthur Ashe in the first day match on Monday. “I thought it might take me more time to find my feet because it’s a little bit of a different court out there,” she said of the tournament’s cavernous main arena. “Flavia has done it before here, and I haven’t. I was just trying to take it all in. “Sometimes you can get a little caught behind the baseline because it’s such a different visual thing out there, more than probably any other court in the world, purely because it is so big. We played on it in the doubles final [last year with compatriot Ashleigh Barty], but it’s different when you have a partner; you’re not hanging out there by yourself.” She did OK by herself, none the less, giving Pennetta a scare in the first set at 4-5 on the Italian’s serve, before fading in the second. “I think she freed up a little bit saving that one,” Dellacqua said, “swung out a little bit. [Then] she found her feet better, her rhythm. “I’m disappointed [with] that loss, but overall I’m happy with where I’m heading, I’m happy with the tournament I’ve had, the tennis I’ve played. I’m definitely not complacent with where I’m at because I’m reaching career highs. In the last 12 months, there was only one way I was going to go, and it was [up]. I need to continue to work hard, consolidate my space in the top 30. “I’m 29, I’m not a spring chicken. I’m not going to go out there and start changing things within my game. I’ve been away for five weeks. I’m looking forward to getting home, seeing [her one-year-old son] Blake, being home, being a mum for the next week, just relaxing, switching off.” After rising a hundred ranking places from 130 a year ago and performing with distinction in a slam against most expectations, she has earned it.
